newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Profit taking pushes S.E Asian currencies higher.
newsitem.headline: Profit taking pushes S.E Asian currencies higher.

text.p: Southeast Asian currencies, rocked by weeks of turmoil, firmed on Friday morning as players cashed in some of their gains on the dollar ahead of the weekend.

Dealers said players were reluctant to establish new positions ahead of the release of Thailand's economic rescue plan, due by August 5, which is expected to include assistance from the International Monetary Fund (IMF).
"Everybody wants to see what the IMF will do in Thailand on the fifth because that will indirectly affect all the other regional currencies," a Singapore-based trader said.

Vague rumours of an impending military coup in Thailand hit New York markets overnight, causing sales of dollar/baht and a rise in swap premiums. But the rumours had been around for weeks and little credence was attached to them, dealers said.
One said there was talk the Bank of Thailand had intervened to sell the dollar around 32.10 baht in Singapore markets on Friday. No confirmation was available.
The baht slipped back a notch from morning highs after Standard & Poor's Corp placed Thailand's "A" long-term foreign currency rating on creditwatch.
That was further bad news for the Thai economy, implying greater than expected loan losses in the crisis-torn financial sector.
The baht was quoted at 31.85/31.95 to the dollar onshore at 0435 GMT against 31.700/9500 late on Thursday. The offshore rate was at 31.80/32.00.
In Malaysia, the ringgit showed little immediate reaction to news Bank Negara Malaysia had asked banks to hold their base lending rates steady.
Banking sources in Kuala Lumpur said the central bank had asked them to hold their base lending rates at 9.67 percent despite a recent spike up in interbank rates.
The ringgit was at 2.6245/95 to the dollar after firming through the 2.63 level earlier on profit-taking in the dollar by funds.
Dealers said the dollar looked firm against the ringgit, but talk of large orders to sell the dollar at the 2.6400 level was likely to limit its rise.
The market was awaiting Malaysia's trade data for June, expected next week, amid talk of a 1.5 billion ringgit deficit after May's surplus of 157 million ringgit.
The Singapore dollar rose through the key 1.47 level to the U.S. dollar but dealers said its rise was likely to be capped around 1.4650.
"This is probably just profit-taking. I'm still looking at a higher dollar/Sing," a dealer said, adding that the market continued to expect the Sing to drop to around 1.50.
Trade in the Indonesian rupiah was slow, dominated by covering of short dollar positions for the weekend. Spot rupiah was at 2,605/15 against an opening of 2,613/23.

The Philippine peso was firmer as banks scrambled to meet a deadline to cut long dollar positions after the central bank slashed the long dollar limit of banks to five percent of capital from 10 percent, or 10 million, whichever is lower.
Newspapers quoted central bank governor Gabriel Singson as saying he expected banks to unload $200 million due to the new ruling. The peso was at 28.960/29.060 against its previous close at 29.
The Taiwan dollar slipped back from an early high of T$28.590, inspired by the central bank's move to raise two key interest rates after the market's close on Thursday.
The central bank raised the rediscount rate to 5.25 percent from 5.00 percent and accomodations against secured loans to 5.625 percent from 5.375 percent, effective from Friday.
Central bank governor Sheu Yuan-dong said the rate hikes were aimed at maintaining stability in the forex market.
The Taiwan dollar was at T$28.653/660 against Thursday's close at T$28.70, its weakest finish since 1988.
